# Agenda



* Comment on our hilariously "effective" p\-hacking routine from last lecture\.

  * We'll address how can we do this in a legitimate way\.

* Introduce regularization and shrinkage

  * Discuss why we should do it\.

* Learn Ridge and LASSO ML algorithms

* Apply them in Code



# Econometrics versus CV



* Econometrics: X\, Y not split into testing and training\.

  * Y\_hat is generated from OLS operating on All Data\.

* In the linear\_regression notebook\, we used Sklearn to automatically solve for the best set of \(two\) coefficients\.

  * In this\, we took our first baby step to CV by splitting into Training and Testing\.

  * We learned SVM applied to this training/testing paradigm\.

* This is still not "Real CV" because we used the Test Data in finding the best set of coefficients\.



![](img\\1242.png)



# Real CV



![](img\\1243.png)



* Therefor\, cross\-validation creates a second split of the training data\.

  * Iteratively solves on this second\-split\.



![](img\\1244.png)



# But that process can be extrapolated up to better utilize our (possibly scarce) data



![](img\\1245.png)



* Keeping track of splits and folds is hard

  * We're going to use GridSearchCV to do it all for us\.



# Reminder on the bias-variance tradeoff



* Reminder: ML lingo uses the word "Variance" in a slightly different way than we're used to:

  * Here\, variance measures the difference in performance between on the training vs testing data

    * This is almost unrelated to the more familiar \(to us\) use of variance to describe a distribution\.



![](img\\1246.png)



![](img\\1247.png)



# One way to reduce variance: Shrinkage



* Shrinkage estimators offer lower variance by construction

  * It's literally just lowering your beta values\.

  * The more we shrink coefficient estimates\, the lower their variance across samples\.

* To build intuition on this\, start with the extreme case: shrink all slope estimates to zero\, make constant predictions\.

  * Performance would be constant\!



# Quick example and implications for bias



# Starting with OLS



* When we have many observations\, OLS does a good job

  * Why? Because with tons of observations\, it is more likely the training data reflect other possible data\.

    * E\.g\.\, suppose we have measurements of weight and size of mice\. Fits pretty well\.



![](img\\1248.png)



# But what if we have fewer data?



* Suppose we only get to fit the data on a small subset \(red\)

  * The resulting estimate is not similar to the full data in green



![](img\\1249.png)



# Variance on out-of-sample observations is huge



![](img\\1250.png)



* Our predicted line will have minimum bias on the training data

  * It's the "Best Linear Unbiased Estimate" \(BLUE\)

* But\, there is huge variance on green\.



* Main idea of regularization:

  * What if we shrink the COEFFICIENT value in the OLS regression

  * This will obviously introduce more bias

* But\, as we will see\, this almost always reduces out\-of\-sample variance

  * This is also referred to as "shrinkage"



# 



![](img\\1251.png)



![](img\\1252.png)



* __Why did we just do this?__

* In general \(VERY VERY OFTEN\) shrinking our coefficients will improve out\-of\-sample performance

  * It is so important that in big data and ML applications\, almost everything is regularized in some way\.

# LASSO: Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator



![](img\\1253.png)



# LASSO: Not just another penalty.



# LASSO and variable selection



* When solved\, LASSO may result in estimates of exactly zero for some parameters\.

  * In other words\, LASSO shrinks parameter estimates\, and shrinks some to zero

  * __This results in automated variable selection__ \.

* Switch to VS Code\, notebook lectures/03\_Regulariation/01\_ridge\_and\_lasso\.ipynb



# So what did we just do?



# Solution: reduce bias by using OLS after



* "post\-LASSO regression"

  * Use LASSO to estimate the main model\, letting it do variable selection

  * Estimate the main model with selected variables from step 1\. This time use OLS\.

* Switch back to our notebook where we will implement this\.



# Appendix



# Elastic Net: LASSO with a ridge



# IV and LASSO



# Motivation



# Many possible instruments in big data contexts



# How many instruments?



* Asymptotic theory:

  * IF all instruments are exogenous and relevant\, then they contain useful information\.

  * For the most efficient \(low variance\) estimator\, we should use all available information\. Question is just how to combine it\.

  * 2SLS can help recover optimal combination of those instruments\.

* But\, we often have finite samples

* And\, having too many instruments can introduce bias\!

  * Hence\, we need some well\-thought\-out model selection approach\.



# Correct for overfitting-bias with LASSO



* If bias arises from overfitting the first stage\, we could try to limit overfitting\.

  * Belloni\, Chen\, Chernozhukov\, Hansen \(2012 Econometrica\): LASSO\!

* Rough idea:

  * Estimate first stage via LASSO \(with specific penalization scheme\)

  * Use instruments selected via LASSO in first stage estimated via OLS

  * Use fitted values in second stage



# Many instruments, many controls



# IV and not LASSO



The world isn't always sparse
